title: How the municipal election works
step1Text: In the municipal election, you receive three different ballots: for the City Council (the "Römer"), for the local council of your district, and – if you are an EU citizen – for the Municipal Foreigners' Advisory Council (KAV).
step2Title: {{count}} votes – as many seats as are being filled
step2Text: For this ballot, you have exactly {{count}} votes. You can distribute all {{count}} votes freely among candidates of all parties.
step3Title: Strategy 1: Vote for an entire list
step3Text: If you trust a party, simply check the list header. Then all candidates on that list receive one vote each, from top to bottom, until your {{count}} votes are used up.
step4Text: You can give a single candidate up to 3 votes – this is called "cumulating". This way you strengthen your favourites.
step5Text: You can distribute your votes among candidates of different parties – this is called "splitting" (panaschieren). Pick the best candidates from all lists!
step6Text: You can also check a list AND additionally vote for individual candidates from other parties. The total must not exceed {{count}}.
step7Title: Caution: This makes your ballot invalid
step7Text: Your ballot is invalid if you cast more than {{count}} votes, check more than one list, or give a candidate more than 3 votes. Watch the counter at the top!
step8Text: Try it yourself with the interactive ballot above. Don't worry – you can't make any mistakes here!
